abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project aims at improving the effectiveness
            of Poland's national road rehabilitation, and
            maintenance systems, with emphasis on quality, efficiency,
            financial viability, and road user satisfaction. In
            accordance with the European Union (EU) laws and regulation,
            Polish legislation on the environment stipulates there is no
            requirement for an environmental impact assessment (EIA) for
            individual sub-projects financed by the Bank loan.
            Nevertheless, Polish law includes provisions on mandatory
            control of environmental risks to soil, land, air, water
            resources, noise emissions, and other, which may result from
            implementation of project activities. The Environmental
            Mitigation Measures Matrix presented in this report
            identifies possible negative impacts on environment, lists
            the regulatory controls and technical guidance applicable in
            roads sector interventions in Poland, specifies the
            mitigation measures inherent in these controls, and a
            summary of the monitoring and reporting measures. Upon
            area-specific conditions, construction contracts for
            sub-projects defined as type "B" projects, will
            refer to specific measures such as prevention of tree
            cutting and runoff control, and specify mandatory
            requirements set by standards and guidelines. In all cases
            the contractors are responsible to observe applicable
            national laws, and are subject to monitoring by
            Environmental Inspectorates during works implementation.
            Project location shall consider potential environmental
            adversity, taking into account: existing land use, relative
            abundance, quality and regenerative capacity of natural
            resources in the area, values of natural environment and
            landscape, conditions of the local land-use plans, having
            regard, in particular, to: wetlands; coastal zones; mountain
            and forest areas; protected areas, including the protection
            zones of water intakes and protection areas of
            surface-waters ponds; special protection areas because of
            existing fauna and flora and natural habitats; areas in
            which the environmental quality standards have already been
            exceeded; populated areas; and, landscapes of historical,
            cultural or archaeological significance. All construction
            works will be subject to a screening criteria, and approval
            of Subproject checklists (attached), to verify environmental
            category, potential environmental adversity, and the
            mitigation measures, if any, required in each case. Overall,
            mitigation reinforces the need for appropriate drainage
            systems; vegetation propagation; maintenance practices to
            reflect the current standards; wastewater treatment and
            groundwater protection; measures to minimize air pollution,
            e.g., water spraying on construction areas; traffic safety
            regulations; and, noise abatement measures.
